headline.main: EQUALITY OF THE SEXES, PLAYBOY STYLE

results.snippet: This is the tale of a rabbit named Louis Affenito of Brooklyn, rather than your usual Flopsy, Mopsy, Bugs or Thumper.   Mr. Affenito is the first of Playboy's male bunnies, to be called rabbits, for the new Playboy Empire Club opening in New York....
results.lead_paragraph: This is the tale of a rabbit named Louis Affenito of Brooklyn, rather than your usual Flopsy, Mopsy, Bugs or Thumper. Mr. Affenito is the first of Playboy's male bunnies, to be called rabbits, for the new Playboy Empire Club opening in New York. The club is to be a prototype, with Playboy planning to have the rabbits multiply like crazy in clubs all over the country. ''I always wanted to be first,'' said Mr. Affenito, a tall, dark carpenter and aspiring actor. ''I came to realize that I would not be the first astronaut or the first to hit 62 home runs. This is an honor.''

headline.main: AS SHUTTLE ORBITS, A DEBATE GROWS OVER MILITARY'S ROLE

results.snippet: As five military officers on the space shuttle Atlantis orbit the earth on a secret mission, a debate is growing in the United States over how much secrecy is necessary in the civilian-run space program and what the military's role in it should be....

byline.original: By WILLIAM J. BROAD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: As five military officers on the space shuttle Atlantis orbit the earth on a secret mission, a debate is growing in the United States over how much secrecy is necessary in the civilian-run space program and what the military's role in it should be. Proponents of an expanded role for the Defense Department say the United States needs to counter a growing Soviet threat in space. They say the Soviet Union conducts four to five times as many space launching a year as the United States, with the vast majority of missions devoted to military objectives. Soviet military officers have, all together, logged years in space, they say, while the American military has logged days. Secrecy is essential, they add, to the success of the Defense Department's space activities.

results.snippet: THE story of D.B. Cooper, the hijacker who parachuted from a Boeing 727 as it flew over the Pacific Northwest in 1971, receives the full treatment in ''D.B. Cooper: What Really Happened,'' by Max Gunther (Contemporary Books, Chicago, $14.95).  ...
results.lead_paragraph: THE story of D.B. Cooper, the hijacker who parachuted from a Boeing 727 as it flew over the Pacific Northwest in 1971, receives the full treatment in ''D.B. Cooper: What Really Happened,'' by Max Gunther (Contemporary Books, Chicago, $14.95). This book, described as ''the incredible true story of the hijacking, escape and years of hiding,'' brings the steadily expanding legend close to home with Mr. Gunther's surprising disclosures about the ''shy, middle-aged'' passenger who threatened to blow up the plane unless he got $200,000 and four parachutes. Up to now, Mr. Gunther writes, the ''tiny town'' of Ariel, Wash., in the region ''where the pirate had apparently landed,'' has ''adopted D.B. Cooper as its own and still holds annual celebrations in his honor.'' But like the classic mystery story, the facts, we are told, are vastly different. Among other things, they involve a sympathetic woman (here named Clara) who, a decade after she had befriended Mr. Cooper, decided to talk to Mr. Gunther.

results.snippet: Under crisp blue skies, a pale crescent moon and with only a handful of spectators as witness, the space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here this morning after its maiden voyage to space.   The four-day mission, operated under strict secrecy rules...

byline.original: By SANDRA BLAKESLEE, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Under crisp blue skies, a pale crescent moon and with only a handful of spectators as witness, the space shuttle Atlantis landed safely here this morning after its maiden voyage to space. The four-day mission, operated under strict secrecy rules imposed by the Department of Defense, ended with military precision. The shuttle touched down just after 10 A.M. At the moment it came to a full stop, at 10:01 and 14 seconds, a recording of ''The Star Spangled Banner'' began playing over loud speakers that are usually dominated by communications with the astronauts. Fewer than a dozen reporters and about two dozen employees of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration were on hand for the landing, an event that usually draws hundreds of spectators. The military had given just 24 hours' notice of when the secret mission was to end and had barred members of the public from watching.

headline.main: MICHAEL APTED: HE'LL BE CALLING AGAIN IN 1991

results.snippet: Michael Apted has learned that he can no longer knock on the same 14 doors every seven years and simply say, ''It's me again.'' The last time he knocked, two of the doors were slammed on his melancholy face, his camera crew, his everlasting...
results.lead_paragraph: Michael Apted has learned that he can no longer knock on the same 14 doors every seven years and simply say, ''It's me again.'' The last time he knocked, two of the doors were slammed on his melancholy face, his camera crew, his everlasting questions. He fears he may be shut out next time by the remaining 12 in a collection of subjects he chose as children in London. His frank and revealing films of their lives at ages 7, 14, 21 and 28 have appeared so often on British television that people in pubs gossip about ''Suzi, the posh girl,'' ''Tony, the tear-away jockey boy'' and the others, as though they were characters in a soap opera. The 44-year-old British director, best known in this country for ''Coal Miner's Daughter,'' says he is not sure how subjects see him. ''To them, I'm probably some exotic bird who lives in Hollywood and makes movies and flies in every seven years to catch up on their lives,'' he was saying the other day at breakfast in a midtown hotel.

headline.main: ROTATING CREWS SEEN FOR SOVIET SPACECRAFT

results.snippet: Soviet space officials said today that they expect to have a permanently manned space station by 1990, but that the Salyut-7 orbital laboratory will not be the spacecraft that hosts the rotating crews.   The first in-flight crew rotation in space...
results.lead_paragraph: Soviet space officials said today that they expect to have a permanently manned space station by 1990, but that the Salyut-7 orbital laboratory will not be the spacecraft that hosts the rotating crews. The first in-flight crew rotation in space was accomplished aboard the Salyut-7 station last month. At a news conference to discuss the recent flights of the astronauts Vladimir Dzhanibekov and Georgi Grechko, an official in charge of space medicine research said last month's feat was only one of several tests preliminary to permanent operations.

headline.main: SCULLY'S TEAM THE WINNER IN PLAYOFFS

results.snippet: The baseball playoffs have so far failed to produce a team that is clearly superior to the competition, but the 10 games have given television viewers a fair chance to compare NBC's two broadcast teams. Parity, it would seem, has not yet arrived in...
results.lead_paragraph: The baseball playoffs have so far failed to produce a team that is clearly superior to the competition, but the 10 games have given television viewers a fair chance to compare NBC's two broadcast teams. Parity, it would seem, has not yet arrived in the broadcast booth. That the National League team of Vin Scully and Joe Garagiola are consistently good, and often even great, is no longer a question. The question is whether their American League counterparts, Bob Costas and Tony Kubek, will ever be in the same league. One hopes so, for they try so hard. Maybe too hard.

results.snippet: THE MEMORY OF the motel sign is still vivid despite the years. Neatly printed black letters on white spelled a puzzling message for a young black boy from suburban St. Louis traveling with his parents through sleepy Arkansas towns with the rural...

byline.original: By Thomas Morgan; Thomas Morgan is an assistant metropolitan editor of The Times

results.lead_paragraph: THE MEMORY OF the motel sign is still vivid despite the years. Neatly printed black letters on white spelled a puzzling message for a young black boy from suburban St. Louis traveling with his parents through sleepy Arkansas towns with the rural charm of Norman Rockwell paintings. The sign read: ''Whites Only.'' When the boy asked about it, his mother answered resignedly, ''It means we can't stay there, son.'' Nearly 30 years have passed since I saw that sign and pondered its message. I have grown and prospered because my father, a postal employee, and my mother, a public-school teacher, sent me, like Moses through the bulrushes, to the shores of new opportunity created by the civil-rights movement. I was one of two blacks to integrate a suburban elementary school in 1958. Later, a white ninth-grade English teacher encouraged me to become a journalist because she saw a spark of writing talent.
